questions.text: A neurotransmitter activates its receptor on an ion channel of a neuron, which causes the water-filled channel to open. When the channel is open, ions move through the channel down their respective electrochemical gradients. A change in membrane potential follows.Which of the following best describes the type of channel and mechanism of ion transport?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

neurotransmitter is a ligand, so when a neurotransmitter binds to its receptor on an ion channel, causing the channel to open, the channel is said to be ligand gated; voltage-gated channels open and close in response to changes in electrical potential across the cell membrane. The mechanism of transport through all water-filled channels is diffusion. Secondary active transport and primary active transport require special transport proteins rather than water-filled channels in the membrane.

questions.text: The axon of a neuron is stimulated experimentally with a 25-millivoltpulse, which initiates an action potential with a velocity of 50 m per second. The axon is then stimulated with a 100-millivolt pulse. What is the action potential velocity after 100Mv stimulation pulse (in meters per second)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The velocity of an action potential is a function of the physical characteristics of the axon (e.g., myelination, axon diameter). A given axon will always conduct any action potential at the same velocity under normal conditions. Therefore, stimulation of the axon with a 25-millivolt pulse or
100 millivolts will produce an action potential with the same velocity, which is why action potentials are said to be “all or none.” However, the level of stimulation must be sufficient to achieve a critical threshold level of potential before an action potential can be initiated in an axon.

questions.text: Volume of bladder is not increasing with increase in pressure because of-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation- Plasticity helps in increase in bladder volume with filling upto a certain limit shown by filling phase.

questions.text: At which point on the nerve action potential shown in the figure given below is the membrane closest to the equilibrium potential for sodium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Point A

When a stimulus is given to a nerve it causes opening of voltage gated sodium channels which increases the membrane permeability for sodium. Sodium entry into the cell causes the cell to depolarize. The potential reaches +30mV (point A), which is closest to the equilibrium potential for sodium (+60mV).

questions.text: Maximum frequency of BER is in which of the following segments of the GI tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The membrane potential of the majority of gastrointestinal smooth muscle undergoes rhythmic fluctuations that sweep along the length of the gut. The rhythm varies in different gut segments and is established by pacemaker cells known as interstitial cells of Cajal. This basic electrical rhythm (BER) provides for sites of muscle contraction when stimuli superimpose spike potentials on the depolarizing portion of the BER waves. The maximum frequency of the BER is in the duodenum at 12/min. The minimum frequency of BER is in the cecum at 2/min.

questions.text: Given below is the length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle. Which point on the graph corresponds to the resting length (also k/a optimum length)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Resting length or optimum length is that initial length at which if a muscle contracts isometrically the tension generated is maximum. It corresponds to a sarcomere length of 2- 2.2 µ.

questions.text: A muscle has 140 mM of a bivalent anion present extracellularly while the intracellular concentration of the same cation is 14 mM. Assuming that 2.3 RT/F = 60 mV, what would be the membrane potential if the membrane were permeable to only this ion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Equilibrium potential (mV) = 2.3 RT/FZ * log C1/C2 
Since it is a bivalent ion, Z = 2
Therefore, the equilibrium potential is 
= (60/2) log140/14
= 30 X log10
= 30mV
Since the membrane is freely permeable to the anion, the ion moves from outside to inside the cell. The inside of the cell becomes negative w.r.t outside. This negative potential inside the cell stops further movement of the anion to reach equilibrium. The potential at equilibrium will, therefore, be --30mV.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is found comatose in her kitchen by her husband and is brought to the Emergency of a nearby hospital. Blood gas analysis reveals normal Po2 and a lower-than-normal arterial O2 saturation. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with the findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CO poisoning

A normal Po2 and lower-than-normal So2 is indicative of anemic hypoxia. CO poisoning causes anemic hypoxia.

questions.text: Transport of glucose from the intestinal lumen into an intestinal epithelial cell is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Secondary active transport
Movement of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal epithelial cell is by secondary active co-transport (SGLT). Glucose leaves the basal side of the cell to enter into the blood with the help of GLUT, which is an example of facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: In an animal experiment, the pancreatic duct is cannulated, and different secretory stimuli are applied to the gland. The following tracings are obtained by measuring the pancreatic fluid constituents. Substance ‘X’ is most likely
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Secretin causes secretion of bicarbonate rich pancreatic juice.

questions.text: Which of the following are best suited to measure the intracellular fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Heavy water and inulin
Measurement of ICF is indirect. ICF = TBW – ECF. Heavy water is most used for measurement of total body eater and Inulin is the most accurate for measurement of ECF volume. A combination of heavy water and inulin is best suited for measurement of ICF.
Radioactive sodium is used for ECF measurement. 
Radioactive iodine labelled albumin is used for measurement of plasma volume.

questions.text: Shown below is the graph of plasma concentration (mg/mL) and clearance (mL/min). Which of the following represents Para amino hippuric acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Para amino hippuric acid in low concentration is freely filtered and completely secreted. The renal clearance of PAH at low concentration is very high. At low concentration, clearance of PAH is equal to the renal plasma flow. But as the plasma concentration of PAH increases there is an incomplete secretion of PAH, decreasing its clearance.

questions.text: The graph given below depicts filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Which of the following are A, B and C respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Polyanionic, neutral, polycationic
Since the basement membrane of the glomerular filtration membrane has a negative charge, anionic substances will have the least filterability. The relative filterability of dextrans of the same molecular weights will be maximum for polycationic dextrans, followed by neutral dextrans and least for polyanionic dextrans.

questions.text: If the average hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries is 50 mm Hg, the hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman’s space is 12 mm Hg, the average colloid osmotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries is 30 mm Hg, and there is no protein in the glomerular ultrafiltrate, what is the net pressure driving glomerular filtration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

8 mm Hg
Since there are no proteins in the glomerular filtrate, the colloid osmotic pressure in the Bowman’s space is 0. 
Net filtration pressure = PGC – πGC – PBC + πBC = 50 – 30 – 12 + 0 = 8 mm Hg

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to her physician with an enlarged thyroid gland and high plasma levels of T4 and T3. Which of the following is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

peripheral resistance

Thyroid hormones increase the metabolic rate in tissues and therefore, vasodilation, increasing blood flow and therefore, cardiac output.

questions.text: Increase in which hormone will produce a change in urine osmolality and urine flow rate as shown in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

With increase in ADH levels , there is more water reabsorption in the collecting duct, so urine osmolarity increases and urine flow rate decreases.

questions.text: In a study to detect extracellular fluid volume, 10 g Mannitol is injected intravenous and after waiting for adequate time for equilibration of levels, concentration was measured as 50 mg / 100 ml. In this time 10% of mannitol was excreted. What is the volume of ECF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Amount injected = 10g , excreted is 10% ,i.e 1g, total retained 10-1 = 9g Conc = 50g/100ml Volume = amount / concentration ; 9/50 x 100 = 18 L.

questions.text: A new mother calls the pediatrician because she is concerned that her infant defecates after meal. Which of the following is the cause of these normal bowel movements in newborns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

gastrocolic reflex Distension of the stomach initiates contraction of the rectum and often, a desire to defecate. This response is called the gastrocolic reflex. This response leads to defecation after meals in infants and children.

questions.text: A healthy 30-year-old woman stand up from the supine position. Which of the following cardiovascular changes are likely in response to standing up from the supine position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased sympathetic activity

On change in posture from supine to standing there is increase in the peripheral pooling of blood. This decreases the venous return, cardiac output and blood pressure. Fall in bp causes a decrease in stretch of the vessel wall and a decrease in the firing rate of the baroreceptors. Decreased firing rate in turn causes a reflex increase in sympathetic discharge and decrease in parasympathetic discharge resulting in increase in heart rate and blood pressure.  Increased sympathetic discharge causes a venoconstriction and decreased venous compliance.

questions.text: A 20-year-old weightlifter is attempting to lift 180 pounds, something which he has never done before. As he attempts to lift the barbell with the weights there is a sudden and complete relaxation of his muscles of arm and forearm, and the barbell falls. Which sensory receptor is most likely to mediate this relaxation of muscles when tension is increased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Golgi tendon organ Whenever there is an excessive increase in muscle tension, the GTO is stimulated which in turn causes a reflex relaxation of the muscles (inverse stretch reflex).

questions.text: A balloon catheter is advanced from the superior vena cava into the right atrium and inflated to increase the right atrial pressure by 5 mm Hg. An increase in which of the following would be expected to occur in response to the elevated atrial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ANP

Increase in RAP increases the secretion of ANP from the myocytes

questions.text: Neurons located in which of the following release serotonin as their neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Raphe magnus nucleus

Raphe magnus nucleus located in the pons secrete serotonin. 
Locus ceruleus- nor epinephrine

choices.text: Plateau phase of the ventricular muscle action potential
Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential
Upstroke of the smooth muscle action potential

questions.text: An increase in calcium conductance is associated with all of the following except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential
Downstroke of the skeletal muscle action potential is due to opening of voltage gated potassium channels and an increase in potassium conductance.

questions.text: The phases of the cardiac action potential are represented by the lettered points on the diagram below. At which point on the action potential is the membrane potential most dependent on calcium permeability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Point C

The plateau phase of the cardiac action potential is due to potassium efflux and a calcium influx through slow calcium channels (also k/a slow sodium- calcium channels).

choices.text: Control and co-ordinate movements of the axial muscles, as well as the shoulder and hip
Control and co-ordinate movements of the distal limb muscles
Function with the cerebral cortex to plan motor movements
Maintain balance and co-ordinate eye movements

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the functional role of the lateral hemispheres of the cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Function with the cerebral cortex to plan motor movements

The lateral cerebellar hemispheres (neocerebellum or cerebro-cerebellum) along with the motor cortex are involved in motor planning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a calcium binding protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clathrin plays a role in endocytosis. Calcium binding proteins are troponin, Calmodulin & Calbindin.

questions.text: Which of the following combination is true about hormone and its site of action in renal tubules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Angiotensin II acts on PCT & TAL of LOH, Aldosterone- Cortical collecting duct & distal tubules ADH on Medullary collecting duct and ANP on Collecting duct.

questions.text: A preterm infant has a surfactant deficiency. Without surfactant, many of the alveoli collapse at the end of each expiration, which in turn leads to pulmonary failure. Which set of changes is present in the preterm infant compared with a normal infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In preterm infant there is decreased production of surfactant so more surface tension and less compliance.

questions.text: In the steady state, which of the following is the same in ICF and ECF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Osmolality

The osmolality of the ICF and ECF is the same. In a healthy adult, the ICF volume is twice as large as the ECF volume. The absolute number of osmoles will, therefore, be higher in the ICF.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is transported by the rescue squad to the emergency department in acute respiratory distress after being stabbed in the left lateral chest. Air can be heard entering the thorax through the stab wound during inspiration, and bubbles form at the stab wound during exhalation. The patient has a 3-cm puncture wound on the left lateral chest between the third and fourth rib. Pulse oximetry shows 85% oxygen saturation. At the end of inspiration, what is the pressure in the patient’s left intrapleural space?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

0 mm Hg
The intrapleural pressure is normally negative w.r.t atmosphere. A puncture of the pleural space as it occurs in this patient will cause air to enter the pleural space till the pleural pressure is equal to the atmospheric pressure. That is, till the pleural pressure is zero. The patient has a low oxygen saturation since there is decreased ventilation of the left lung.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician’s office complaining of trembling in his hands and difficulty walking. Neurologic examination shows the patient has a resting tremor of the left hand that diminishes when performing a task. During passive movement of the left arm, the muscles are rigid, causing “cogwheel” motion during stretching. The patient’s facial expressions are reduced. When walking, the patient has difficulty taking the first step but then is able to walk smoothly with a shuffling gait. These symptoms are consistent with damage to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Substantia nigra

Parkinson’s disease is a progressive degenerative motor disease that results from damage to the dopamine secreting neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta of the basal ganglia. Parkinson’s disease has a gradual onset, often beginning with mild tremor of the hands or feet while at rest. This tremor is different than the intention tremor characteristic of cerebellar diseases. As the disease progresses, the tremor can become more pronounced and additional symptoms of bradykinesia, slowness of movement, postural instability, and impaired balance may develop. In advanced states there are emotional changes as well as difficulty with swallowing and speaking. The disease is difficult to diagnose because there are biomarkers or imaging defects characteristic to Parkinson’s disease.

choices.text: It produces its effect by activating cAMP
It produces its effect by increasing the distal tubular permeability to sodium
It causes an increased secretion of hydrogen ions
It is secreted in response to decrease in blood pressure

questions.text: All except the following characterize the production and actions of aldosterone in the body-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aldosterone binds to an intracytoplasmic receptor that causes an increased synthesis of proteins, including the Na+- K+ ATPase pumps, ENaCs, K+ channels, which together increase the sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the tubular cells of the distal nephron. Aldosterone also increases the H+ secretion in the distal nephron. Aldosterone secretion is stimulated by a decrease in blood volume (through the renin- angiotensin system) and by an increased plasma K+ concentration.

choices.text: Increased activity of the cortical neurons
Decrease in arterial blood pressure from 120 mm to 90 mm Hg

questions.text: All except the following factors increase the cerebral blood flow-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Between MAP of 65 and 140mm Hg, cerebral blood flow is constant. Decrease in arterial pressure from 120 to 90 mm Hg will not affect cerebral blood flow. Cerebral blood flow is regulated by local metabolites, such as, local decrease in O2, increase in CO2, increase in K+, increased activity in the cortical neurons.

questions.text: If - 1. First heart sound 2. “a” wave 3. Rapid ejection phase 4. T wave Which of the following is the correct sequence in the cardiac cycle after P wave of ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2, 1, 3, 4
Atrial depolarization or P wave of ECG is followed by atrial contraction or the “a” wave of JVP. “a” wave of JVP coincides with the second rapid filling phase towards the end of ventricular diastole. First heart sound marks the end of diastole and the beginning of systole. First phase of systole is isovolumetric contraction phase followed by the rapid and slow ejection phases. 
An easy way to remember the sequence of events in the cardiac cycle is :
P a Q R 1 c x T 2 v 3 y

choices.text: Normal individuals after waking in the morning
Normal individuals who have taken dexamethasone

questions.text: When compared with the late-evening values typically observed in normal individuals, plasma levels of both ACTH and cortisol would be expected to be higher in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Normal individuals after waking in the morning
In healthy subjects, the secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are low in the late evening but high in the early morning. In patients with Cushing’s syndrome (adrenal adenoma) or in patients taking dexamethasone, plasma levels of ACTH will be very low. In patients with Addison’s plasma levels of ACTH will be elevated due to deficient adrenal cortisol secretion.

questions.text: SCFA absorption occurs almost exclusively form which of the following segments of the GI tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Colon

Colon is the major site of production and absorption of SCFAs. SCFAs are produced by colonic bacteria which act on dietary fibre and undigested complex carbohydrates. In addition to having a trophic action on the colonic mucosa, they are believed to promote sodium absorption from the colon.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male has a murmur that ceases with the onset of the second heart sound. Second heart sound occurs at the onset of which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

isovolumetric relaxation

Second heart sound marks the end of systole and beginning of diastole. The first phase of diastole is the isovolumetric relaxation phase.

questions.text: A group of students decide to go hiking while visiting Leh. After 3 hours, one of them becomes disoriented, ataxic, short of breath and starts vomiting. A diagnostic work-up at a nearby hospital shows a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
PaCO2
High altitude causes a hypoxic hypoxia, which in turn stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors increasing the rate and depth of ventilation. Increase in alveolar ventilation causes a CO2 washout and respiatory alkalosis increasing the pH. Hypoxia will cause a pulmonary vasoconstriction increasing the pulmonary vascular resistance. In high altitude, glycolysis increases which in turn causes increase in 2,3- BPG.

questions.text: Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors mediate increased ventilation in response to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypercapnia
Both the peripheral and central chemoreceptors respond to an increase in Paco2 levels. The peripheral chemoreceptors also cause an increase in ventilation in response to a decrease in arterial pH and a decrease in Pao2. The central chemoreceptors are unresponsive to hypoxemia or to a decrease in arterial pH.

choices.text: Blood pressure and heart rate increase
Blood pressure and heart rate decrease
Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases
Blood pressure decreases and heart rate increases

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has a fall from his cycle and sustains a skull fracture which compresses the underlying brain tissue. Which of the following will occur in response to an increased intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blood pressure increases and heart rate decreases
Increase in intracranial pressure decreases cerebral blood flow producing CNS ischemia. This in turn increase sympathetic discharge increasing the blood pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors producing a reflex bradycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following motor pathways innervate the A gamma motor neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reticulospinal tract

Reticulospinal tracts- pontine/ excitatory and medullary/ inhibitory tracts innervate the A gamma motor neurons especially to the lower limb extensors, thereby, controlling extensor muscle tone.

questions.text: A large dose of insulin is administered to a patient. Which of the following hormonal changes are NOT likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increase in aldosterone
Injection of Insulin leads to decrease in blood glucose. Hypoglycemia stimulates the secretion of GH, glucagon and epinephrine, all of which have counter- regulatory effects to increase the glucose levels in the blood. Hypoglycemia does not increase the aldosterone levels.

questions.text: Which condition at the S-A node will cause the heart rate to decrease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased potassium permeability
Increases in sodium and calcium permeability at the S-A node result in an increase in heart rate. An increased potassium permeability causes a hyperpolarization of the S-A node, which causes the heart rate to decrease.

questions.text: In control conditions, flow through a blood vessel is 100 ml/min under a pressure gradient of 200 mm Hg. What would be the approximate flow through the vessel after increasing the vessel diameter to two times normal, assuming that the pressure gradient was maintained at 200 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

1600 ml/min

According to Poiseuille’s law, flow through a vessel increases in proportion to the fourth power of the radius. A 2-fold increase in vessel diameter (or radius) would increase 2 to the fourth power, or 16 times normal. Thus, flow through the vessel after increasing the vessel 4 times normal would increase from 100 to 1600 ml/min.

questions.text: If a person maintains a high (150 mmol/day) potassium diet, which part of the nephron would be expected to secrete the most potassium? Choose the appropriate nephron site in the figure below-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (F)

Approximately 65% of the filtered load of potassium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. Variations in renal excretion of potassium during change in potassium intake are achieved mainly by changes in potassium secretion in collecting tubules. With high potassium intake, the proximal tubule still reabsorbs a high fraction of the filtered load of potassium.

questions.text: Unconscious proprioception is carried by-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Unconscious proprioception is carried by spinocerebellar tract and conscious proprioception by dorsal column tract.

questions.text: Which of the following is higher at the apex of the lung than the base when the person is standing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
V/Q ratio is maximum at the apex . PaO2 is maximum at apex - as apical alveoli are both underventilated and underperfused but far more underperfused than underventilated.

questions.text: An important non- respiratory function of the Lungs:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 
 Lungs play an indirect role in Na+ balance as ACE is present in pulmonary endothelial capillaries, which catalyzes conversion of Ang – I to Ang – II which releases aldosterone.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man resents with polyuria and polydipsia. Blood analysis reveals hypernatremia, and urinalysis shows hypotonicity with increased free water clearance. In which of the following conditions is an increased free water clearance a hallmark of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diabetes insipidus

In Diabetes insipidus, lack of ADH causes excretion of large volumes of extremely dilute urine, increasing the free water clearance.

choices.text: Myosin head detachment from the actin molecule
Displacement of tropomyosin exposing the active sites on actin

questions.text: As part of an experiment, radiolabeled ATP is injected into the skeletal muscle. During muscle contraction, the labeled ATP is observed to attach to the sarcomere. This attachment causes immediate-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myosin head detachment from the actin molecule

In actin- myosin cross- bridge cycling attachment of ATP causes an immediate detachment of head. 
Calcium binding to troponin-C, causes a conformational change in troponin which causes displacement of tropomyosin exposing the active sites on actin and resulting in actin- myosin cross bridge formation.

questions.text: When the respiratory drive for increased pulmonary ventilation becomes greater than normal, a special set of neurons that are inactive during normal breathing then become active, contributing to the respiratory drive. These neurons are located in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ventral respiratory group The I neurons of the DRG are responsible for the basic rhythm of tidal respiration. When the respiratory drive for increased pulmonary ventilation becomes greater than normal, respiratory signals spill over into the VRG, causing the VRG to contribute to the respiratory drive. Neurons of the VRG are inactive during normal quiet breathing.

questions.text: The following laboratory values were obtained in a 58-year-old man: Urine flow rate = 3 ml/min. Serum creatinine = 3 mg/100 ml Urine creatinine = 50 mg/100 ml Plasma potassium = 4.0 mmol/l Urine potassium = 30 mmol/l What is his approximate GFR, assuming that he collected all of his urine in the 24-hour period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


GFR is approximately equal to creatinine clearance, which is calculated as the urine creatinine concentration (50 mg/100 ml) × urine flow rate (3 ml/min)/plasma creatinine concentration (3 mg/100 ml), which is equal to 50 ml/min.

choices.text: None of the above (breathing would remain normal)

questions.text: A stroke that destroys the respiratory area of the medulla would be expected to lead to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The respiratory area of the medulla controls all aspects of respiration, so a destruction of this area would cause a cessation of breathing.

choices.text: Increasing glomerular capillary colloid oncotic pressure
Increasing hydrostatic pressure in Bowman’s space

questions.text: A patient presents with a twofold-elevated serum creatinine level compared to baseline for 12 hours. In order to prevent worsening azotemia, the patient’s glomerular filtration rate must be increased. Which of the following is an appropriate manipulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Dilating the afferent arteriole increases hydrostatic glomerular capillary pressure (PGC). This increases the force that drives plasma from the capillary into the capsule and increases glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Constricting the afferent arteriole or dilating the efferent arteriole decreases PGC and thus decreases GFR. Increasing the glomerular capillary colloid oncotic pressure will draw fluid from Bowman’s capsule into the capillary, hence decrease GFR. Increasing hydrostatic pressure in Bowman’s space, such as seen in postrenal failure, opposes filtration and decreases GFR.

questions.text: A transmitter substance released from a presynaptic neuron causes the membrane potential of a postsynaptic neuron to change from −60 millivolts to −62 millivolts. Which of the following best describes this change in membrane potential (in millivolts)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


The decrease in membrane potential to a more negative value is called the inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP). Because the resting membrane potential is −60 millivolts and the final membrane potential is −62 millivolts, the IPSP is -2 millivolts. IPSPs are always negative. Excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) are always positive because the membrane potential is increased to a less negative value.

choices.text: Affinity for nuclear receptors in target tissues

questions.text: Which physiological response is greater for T3 than for T4?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


In target tissues, nuclear receptors for thyroid hormones have a greater affinity for T3 than for T4. The secretion rate, plasma concentration, half-life, and onset of action are all greater for T4 than for T3.

questions.text: Which of the following is an encapsulated receptor found deep in the skin throughout the body, as well as in fascial layers, where it detects indentation of the skin (pressure) and movement across the surface (vibration)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


 Pacinian corpuscles detect pressure and movement across the skin surface and are encapsulated receptors found deep in the skin throughout the body.

choices.text: PTH inhibits the production of vitamin D hormones
PTH promotes bone resorption in response to decreased plasma calcium
PTH promotes the movement of calcium from bone fluid to the extracellular fluid
PTH promotes calcium reabsorption in the renal distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: All of the following statements about parathyroid hormone are true EXCEPT one. Which one is the exception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


One of the major physiological roles for PTH is to promote the conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol, to the active 1,25- dihydroxycholecalciferol in the proximal tubular epithelium. The other choices represent normal physiological actions of PTH.

questions.text: You have transfused a 1 liter of blood into your dehydrated patient. At any instant, most of this blood will be found in which segment of the systemic vascular bed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Veins - 2/3 of the blood is in the venous side.

questions.text: 33-year-old woman is injured in a car accident and is bleeding profusely. When the ambulance arrives, she is hypotensive and tachycardic. The paramedic starts intravenous fluid replacement but accidentally infuses 800 mL of sterile pure water instead of normal saline solution. What effect will this infusion have on her plasma osmolarity and on the shape of her red blood cells (RBC)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 
Normal saline, a 0.9% sodium chloride solution, is isotonic with blood and is most commonly used for fluid resuscitation. Pure water is hypotonic to blood and therefore reduces the plasma osmolality, making it hypoosmotic compared to normal. In this state, water will diffuse into the red blood cells until NaCl concentration is equal inside and outside of the cells. This will cause the cells to swell and possibly lyse.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the Emergency with shortness of breath. His OHDC was shifted from that for normal hemoglobin A depicted in the curve A in the figure given below to curve B. this finding is consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Recent transfusion with banked blood

In banked blood, glycolysis is inhibited which decreases the 2,3-BPG, shifting the OHDC to the left.

questions.text: Parathormone increases calcium reabsorption in which of the following points along the nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DCT

PTH decreases inorganic phosphorus reabsorption in the PCT and increases calcium reabsorption in the DCT.

choices.text: Increased intracellular chloride concentration, decreased cell volume
Decreased intracellular chloride concentration, increased cell volume
Decreased intracellular chloride concentration, decreased cell volume
Increased intracellular chloride concentration, increased cell volume

questions.text: Compared with arterial red blood cells, which of the following best describes the venous red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increased intracellular chloride concentration, increased cell volume
CO2 combines with water in the RBCs to form carbonic acid which dissociates into HCO3- and H+ ions. Bicarbonate diffuses out of the RBCs, whereas the chloride diffuses into the cells to maintain electrical neutrality. The phenomenon, called chloride shift occurs due to a special protein called AE-1 present in the RBC membrane that shuttles the ions in the opposite directions. Water moves into the RBCs to maintain osmotic equilibrium, which results in slight increase in size of the venous RBCs.

questions.text: Which of the following vasoactive agents is usually the most important controller of coronary blood flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Adenosine
Although bradykinin, prostaglandins, potassium ions cause a coronary vasodilation but he major controller of coronary blood flow is adenosine.

questions.text: After secretion of trypsinogen into the duodenum, the enzyme is converted into its active form, trypsin, by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Enteropeptidase

Enteropeptidase or enterokinase converts trypsinogen into its active form- trypsin Trypsin in turn will inactivate all inactive pancreatic proteolytic enzymes to their active form.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with severe kyphoscoliosis and respiratory muscle weakness. Which of the following physiological variables is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

chest wall compliance
Kyphoscoliosis is a restrictive lung disease. In RLD, all lung volumes and chest wall compliance decrease but FEV1/ FVC ratio is normal to increased. Decreased chest wall compliance and respiratory muscle weakness cause inadequate alveolar ventilation which leads to accumulation of CO2 and respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents with lethargy, confusion and muscle cramps. Lab investigations reveal elevated ADH levels, possible from the ectopic production of ADH. In patients with SIADH, which of the following will increase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intracellular volume

ADH will increase water reabsorption increasing the ECF volume and decreasing the plasma sodium and plasma osmolality. Decrease in plasma osmolality will cause shift of water from ECf to ICF increasing the intracellular volume. Since there is increased reabsorption of water urine flow rate will decrease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man, victim of road traffic accident is brought to the Emergency and is diagnosed with hemisection of the left side of the spinal cord at C6. Which of the following function is likely to be lost in the right leg of this man?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pain and temperature

This is a patient of Brown Sequard syndrome. Pain and temperature will be lost on the opposite side below the level of lesion.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy fell from his bicycle and sustained a head injury. He develops a fever of 39 degrees Celsius which is unrelated to an infection or inflammation. The fever is most likely due to a lesion of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anterior hypothalamus
Anterior hypothalamus is responsible for initiating reflexes such as, vasodilation and sweating, which help reduce body temperature. Lesion of this area can therefore, increase body temperature.

questions.text: Synaptic transmission between the pain fibres from the viscera in the pelvis to spinal cord neurons is mediated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Substance P

The neurotransmitter secreted by C fibres for visceral pain is substance P.

questions.text: The circadian rhythm is controlled by which hypothalamic nucleus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Suprachiasmatic

Suprachiasmatic nucleus controls secretion of melatonin from the pineal gland. Melatonin, in turn, is responsible for a number of circadian rhythms, including sleep-wake cycles.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male running in airtel half marathon since last three hours on a hot summer day was sweating profusely but did not drink fluids. He is brought to the Emergency with a fever of 101 degrees F and heart rate of 150 beats/ min, his blood pressure measured was 100/68 mm Hg in the supine position. Upon examination he has no perspiration, appears to have dry mucus membranes, and is poorly oriented to person, place and time. Assuming his kidneys were normal, which of the following hormone changes will be least likely seen in this patient, compared with normal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Sweating causes an increase in plasma osmolality which in turn increases ADH secretion. Hypovolemia due to the dehydration increases Renin secretion from the JG cells which in turn in turn increases Angiotensin II and Aldosterone. Increase in blood volume causes an increase in ANP.

choices.text: Voltage- gated calcium channels on pre- synaptic membrane
Voltage- gated calcium channels on post- synaptic membrane
Ligand- gated sodium channels on pre- synaptic membrane
Ligand- gated sodium channels on post- synaptic membrane

questions.text: A 65- year-old man presented with progressive leg weakness and a diagnosis of LEMS (Lambert- Eaton myasthenic syndrome) was made by serial repetitive nerve stimulation test. Which of the following channels are affected in Lambert-Eaton syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Voltage-gated calcium channels on pre- synaptic membrane • LEMS is caused by an auto-immune attach against voltage-gated calcium channels on the pre-synaptic membrane at the NMJ. • It is usually adult- onset and has a similar occurrence in males and females. Proximal muscles of the lower extremities are primarily affected, producing a waddling gait and difficulty in raising arms. • Repetitive stimulation of the motor nerve facilitates accumulation of calcium in the nerve terminal and increases acetylcholine release, leading to increase in muscle strength. This is in contrast to myasthenia gravis in which symptoms are exacerbated by repetitive stimulation.

questions.text: While playing football, the ball hits a 12-year old boy on his shin with considerable force. He sits on the ground and starts rubbing the area to reduce the pain. Inhibition of pain signals by tactile stimulation of the skin is mediated by which type of afferent neurons from the mechanoreceptors-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aβ

By rubbing the area touch receptors are stimulated. Touch sensation carried by type Aβ fibres causes a pre-synaptic inhibition of the pain pathway in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (Gate control theory of Melzac and Wall).

choices.text: Secretion is stimulated by somatostatin and inhibited by ghrelin
It has a long half life
It stimulates production of IGF-1 by the liver

questions.text: A 33-year-old national level basketball player takes human growth hormone to increase his performance. Which of the following best describes human growth hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It stimulates production of IGF-1 by the liver GH exerts many of its effects on growth and metabolism by stimulating the production and release of somatomedins from the liver, cartilage and other tissues. The principal somatomedin in humans is somatomedin-C (also k/a IGF-1). GH release is stimulated by GHRH from the hypothalamus and ghrelin from the stomach. GH is not bound to a protein and therefore, has a short half-life. GH increases protein synthesis and is therefore, anabolic.
